Literature Review: The molecular and cellular mechanisms of salt taste are complex and involve multiple pathways. Research has shown that sodium-dependent and -independent pathways mediate attraction and aversion to NaCl, respectively. The ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) plays a crucial role in the perception of salt taste, as it is responsible for the influx of sodium ions into the taste cells. This influx of sodium ions triggers a signaling cascade that ultimately leads to the perception of salt taste. In addition to ENaC, other taste receptors such as the T1R (taste receptor type 1) and T2R (taste receptor type 2) have also been implicated in the perception of salt taste. These receptors are responsible for detecting the presence of sodium ions and triggering a signaling cascade that ultimately leads to the perception of salt taste. The valence of salt taste is also a critical aspect of its perception, with low salt concentrations being attractive and high salt concentrations being repulsive. This concentration-valence relationship is universally observed in terrestrial animals and is thought to be mediated by the ENaC and other taste receptors. In insects, the perception of salt taste is also mediated by ENaC and other taste receptors, although the specific mechanisms involved are less well understood. Recent advances in our understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying salt taste have provided new insights into the complex peripheral codes for NaCl. These advances have also highlighted the importance of the ENaC in the perception of salt taste and have provided new targets for the development of salt taste disorders. However, much remains unknown, and further research is needed to fully understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying salt taste in mammals and insects.
